how would I adjust this cmake list so i can divide .cpp files and. h ones into two folders instead of all being in src folder?
To organize your .cpp and .h files into separate folders (commonly named "src" for source files and "include" for header files), you can modify your CMakeLists.txt like this:

```cmake
# Adjust include directories
include_directories(${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/include)

# Add source files
file(GLOB SOURCES "src/*.cpp")
file(GLOB HEADERS "include/*.h")

# Add executable with both sources and headers
add_executable(YourExecutableName ${SOURCES} ${HEADERS})
```

Here's what you need to do:

1. Create two folders in your project:
   - `src/` for .cpp files
   - `include/` for .h files

2. Move your .cpp files to the `src/` folder
3. Move your .h files to the `include/` folder

The `include_directories()` command tells CMake where to look for header files when compiling.

If you have a specific project structure in mind or if you're working with an existing CMakeLists.txt, feel free to share it and I can provide more specific guidance.
cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.15)
project(reasings)

# Enable compilation database for IDEs and tools
set(CMAKE_EXPORT_COMPILE_COMMANDS ON)

# Set C++ standard
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)

# Add include and library directories
include_directories(${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/include)
link_directories(${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/lib)

# Add the executable
file(GLOB SOURCES ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/src/*.cpp)
add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} ${SOURCES})

# Link the Raylib library
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} raylib)

# Platform-specific settings for Raylib
if(APPLE)
    target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} "-framework OpenGL" "-framework Cocoa" "-framework IOKit" "-framework CoreVideo")
elseif(UNIX)
    target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} m pthread dl rt X11)
endif()

Here's your CMakeLists.txt adjusted to handle separate src and include folders:

```cmake
ncmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.15)
project(reasings)

# Enable compilation database for IDEs and tools
set(CMAKE_EXPORT_COMPILE_COMMANDS ON)

# Set C++ standard
set(CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD 17)

# Add include and library directories
include_directories(${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/include)
link_directories(${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/lib)

# Add source and header files
file(GLOB SOURCES ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/src/*.cpp)
file(GLOB HEADERS ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/include/*.h)

# Add the executable with both sources and headers
add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} ${SOURCES} ${HEADERS})

# Link the Raylib library
target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} raylib)

# Platform-specific settings for Raylib
if(APPLE)
    target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} "-framework OpenGL" "-framework Cocoa" "-framework IOKit" "-framework CoreVideo")
elseif(UNIX)
    target_link_libraries(${PROJECT_NAME} m pthread dl rt X11)
endif()
```

The main changes are:

1. Added a line to gather header files:
```cmake
file(GLOB HEADERS ${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/include/*.h)
```

2. Modified the add_executable line to include both sources and headers:
```cmake
add_executable(${PROJECT_NAME} ${SOURCES} ${HEADERS})
```

The include_directories line was already correctly set up for the include folder.

Now you just need to:
1. Create an `include` folder in your project root if it doesn't exist
2. Move all your .h files to the `include` folder
3. Keep all your .cpp files in the `src` folder

Your project structure should look like this:
```
project_root/
├── CMakeLists.txt
├── src/
│   └── *.cpp files
├── include/
│   └── *.h files
└── lib/
```
In terminal, how do i clean my build directory and rebuild it using cmake, like what are the commands be short

Here's the quick sequence to clean and rebuild:

```bash
rm -rf build/*    # Clean build directory
cd build          # Enter build directory
cmake ..          # Configure CMake
make              # Build project
```

Or if you need to recreate the build directory entirely:
```bash
rm -rf build      # Delete build directory
mkdir build       # Create new build directory
cd build          # Enter build directory
cmake ..          # Configure CMake
make              # Build project
